```diff
+ # How It Works
+ 
+ &gt; Plain-English explanations of how this site works under the hood.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## The Big Picture
+ 
+ Studio Queral is a personal website that does three main things:
+ 
+ 1. **Shows an interactive homepage** with a WebGL morph effect
+ 2. **Displays Cursor AI conversation logs** as navigable web pages
+ 3. **Collects newsletter signups** via Buttondown
+ 
+ Think of it like a portfolio site with a reading room attached.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## The Cursor Log Viewer
+ 
+ ### What It Is
+ 
+ A system that transforms exported Cursor AI conversations into beautiful, navigable web pagesâ€”like turning a chat transcript into a polished blog post.
+ 
+ ### Why It Matters
+ 
+ Raw Cursor exports are just markdown files. This viewer makes them scannable, searchable, and shareable.
+ 
+ ### The Analogy
+ 
+ Imagine you have a box of handwritten letters. The log viewer is like a librarian who:
+ 1. Reads through the letters
+ 2. Identifies each conversation turn (who said what)
+ 3. Creates an index of all the questions asked
+ 4. Arranges everything in a reading room with a table of contents
+ 
+ ### How It Works
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;

+ **Step by step:**

+ 1. **You export a conversation** from Cursor â†’ drops a &#96;.md&#96; file
+ 2. **You place it in &#96;public/logs/&#96;** and add an entry to &#96;manifest.json&#96;
+ 3. **User visits &#96;/logs/your-slug&#96;** â†’ React Router loads CursorLogPage
+ 4. **CursorLogPage fetches the markdown** from the public folder
+ 5. **The parser (&#96;parseCursorLog.js&#96;) splits it** into structured data
+ 6. **Components render each piece** with appropriate styling
+ 
+ ### The Parser Logic
+ 
+ The parser looks for specific patterns in Cursor&#39;s export format:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ **User** (timestamp)          â† Identifies a user message block
+ ...user content...
+ 
+ **Cursor** (model info)       â† Identifies an AI response block
+ ...cursor content...
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ It also handles SpecStory format exports, which look slightly different:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ _**User (timestamp)**_        â† SpecStory user format
+ _**Agent (model)**_           â† SpecStory agent format
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### The Sticky Navigation
+ 
+ As you scroll through a long conversation, questions can get buried. The sticky nav solves this by:
+ 
+ 1. **Extracting every user question** (looks for &#96;**User**&#96; blocks)
+ 2. **Creating clickable links** in a sidebar
+ 3. **Tracking scroll position** to highlight current section
+ 4. **Enabling smooth scrolling** when you click a question
+ 
+ It&#39;s like having bookmarks that update as you read.
+ 
+ ---
+

+ ### What It Is

+ An interactive image effect on the homepage that morphs between two photos with various visual distortions.
+ 
+ ### Why It Matters

+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
```

```diff
- 
+ # Architecture
+ 
+ &gt; Technical design decisions and their rationale.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Tech Stack Decisions
+ 
+ ### React + Vite (Not Next.js)
+ 
+ **Decision:** Use plain React with Vite instead of Next.js.
+ 
+ **Rationale:** This is a simple portfolio site with:
+ - No server-side rendering needs (content is mostly static)
+ - No complex routing requirements
+ - No database
+ - Fast iteration speed matters more than SEO optimization
+ 
+ Vite provides instant HMR and fast builds. The added complexity of Next.js isn&#39;t justified here.
+ 
+ ### Tachyons CSS (Not Tailwind)
+ 
+ **Decision:** Use Tachyons functional CSS.
+ 
+ **Rationale:** 
+ - Smaller footprint than Tailwind
+ - No build process for CSS
+ - Sufficient for this project&#39;s needs
+ - Personal preference for its naming conventions
+ 
+ Extended in &#96;tachyons-ext.css&#96; for custom utilities.
+ 
+ ### Client-Side Routing
+ 
+ **Decision:** Use React Router for SPA routing.
+ 
+ **Rationale:**
+ - All routes are truly client-side (no SSR)
+ - Simple mental model
+ - Works well with Vercel&#39;s static hosting
+ 
+ The &#96;vercel.json&#96; rewrites handle the SPA fallback:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;json
+ {
+   &quot;rewrites&quot;: [{ &quot;source&quot;: &quot;/(.*)&quot;, &quot;destination&quot;: &quot;/index.html&quot; }]
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Component Architecture
+ 
+ ### Directory Structure
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ src/
+ â”œâ”€â”€ components/           # Reusable UI components
+ â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ CursorLog/       # Log viewer domain (grouped feature)

+ â”œâ”€â”€ pages/               # Route entry points

+ â”œâ”€â”€ utils/               # Pure functions, no React
+ â”‚   â””â”€â”€ parseCursorLog.js

+     â”œâ”€â”€ tachyons-ext.css

+ ### Component Boundaries
+ 
+ **CursorLog Feature:**

+ - &#96;LogViewer&#96; â€“ Orchestrates parsing and layout
+ - &#96;StickyNav&#96; â€“ Navigation sidebar, manages scroll tracking
+ - &#96;ConversationBlock&#96; â€“ Renders individual user/AI message

+ - &#96;HomePage&#96; â€“ Main content, random takes logic

+ ## Data Flow

+ ### Log Viewer Data Flow
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ URL param (:slug)
+        â”‚
+        â–¼
+ CursorLogPage
+        â”‚
+        â”œâ”€â”€â”€ fetch(&#96;/logs/${slug}.md&#96;)
+        â”‚
+        â–¼
+ parseCursorLog(markdown)
+        â”‚
+        â”œâ”€â”€â”€ Returns: { title, metadata, blocks, questions }
+        â”‚
+        â–¼
+ LogViewer receives parsed data
+        â”‚
+        â”œâ”€â”€â”€ Passes questions â†’ StickyNav
+        â”‚
+        â””â”€â”€â”€ Maps blocks â†’ ConversationBlock[]
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### State Management
+ 
+ **No global state library.** React&#39;s built-in useState and useRef are sufficient:
+ 
+ | State | Location | Why |
+ |-------|----------|-----|
+ | Parsed log data | CursorLogPage | Fetched once, passed down |
+ | Current question (scroll) | StickyNav | Local scroll tracking |
+ | Morph value | WebGLMorpher | Slider-controlled local state |
+ | Form state | NewsletterSignup | Local form management |
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Cursor Log Parser Design
+ 
+ ### Why a Custom Parser?
+ 
+ Cursor exports have a specific format that markdown renderers don&#39;t understand semantically. We need to:
+ 
+ 1. Distinguish User from AI messages
+ 2. Extract questions for navigation
+ 3. Handle both Cursor export and SpecStory formats
+ 4. Preserve code blocks with language info
+ 
+ ### Parser Output Shape
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;typescript
+ interface ParsedLog {
+   title: string;              // Extracted from first heading
+   metadata: {
+     date?: string;
+     version?: string;
+   };
+   blocks: MessageBlock[];     // The conversation
+   questions: Question[];      // For sticky nav
+ }
+ 
+ interface MessageBlock {
+   speaker: &#39;user&#39; | &#39;cursor&#39;;
+   content: string;            // Markdown content
+   timestamp?: string;
+   model?: string;             // For AI responses
+   thinking?: string[];        // AI thinking blocks (if present)
+ }
+ 
+ interface Question {
+   id: string;                 // For scroll targeting
+   text: string;               // Truncated question text
+   blockIndex: number;         // Which block it&#39;s from
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### Format Detection
+ 
+ The parser auto-detects format based on markers:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;javascript
+ if (content.includes(&#39;_**User&#39;)) {
+   // SpecStory format
+ } else if (content.includes(&#39;**User**&#39;)) {
+   // Standard Cursor export
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## WebGL Component Design
+ 
+ ### Isolation
+ 
+ &#96;WebGLMorpher&#96; is fully self-contained:
+ - Creates and manages its own canvas
+ - Loads textures from public folder
+ - Compiles shaders internally
+ - Cleans up on unmount
+ 
+ No WebGL state leaks outside the component.
+ 
+ ### Resource Management
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;javascript
+ useEffect(() =&gt; {
+   // Initialize WebGL context, compile shaders, load textures
+   return () =&gt; {
+     // Clean up: delete textures, delete program, lose context
+   };
+ }, []);
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### Animation Pattern
+ 
+ Uses &#96;requestAnimationFrame&#96; with refs (not state) to avoid stale closure issues:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;javascript
+ const morphValueRef = useRef(0);
+ 
+ // Update ref when state changes
+ useEffect(() =&gt; {
+   morphValueRef.current = morphValue;
+ }, [morphValue]);
+ 
+ // Animation loop reads ref, not state
+ function animate() {
+   render(morphValueRef.current);
+   requestAnimationFrame(animate);
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## API Design
+ 
+ ### Newsletter Subscription
+ 
+ **Endpoint:** &#96;POST /api/subscribe&#96;
+ 
+ **Request:**
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;json
+ { &quot;email&quot;: &quot;user@example.com&quot; }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ **Response:**
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;json
+ { &quot;success&quot;: true }
+ // or
+ { &quot;success&quot;: false, &quot;error&quot;: &quot;message&quot; }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ **Implementation:** Vercel serverless function at &#96;api/subscribe.js&#96;
+ 
+ **Security:**
+ - API key stored in environment variable
+ - Never exposed to client
+ - Rate limiting handled by Buttondown
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Deployment Architecture
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
+ â”‚                        Vercel                           â”‚
+ â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
+ â”‚                                                         â”‚
+ â”‚  â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”    â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”â”‚
+ â”‚  â”‚  Static Files   â”‚    â”‚    Serverless Functions     â”‚â”‚
+ â”‚  â”‚  (dist/)        â”‚    â”‚    (api/)                   â”‚â”‚
+ â”‚  â”‚                 â”‚    â”‚                             â”‚â”‚
+ â”‚  â”‚  - index.html   â”‚    â”‚  - subscribe.js             â”‚â”‚
+ â”‚  â”‚  - assets/      â”‚    â”‚                             â”‚â”‚
+ â”‚  â”‚  - images/      â”‚    â”‚                             â”‚â”‚
+ â”‚  â”‚  - logs/        â”‚    â”‚                             â”‚â”‚
+ â”‚  â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜    â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜â”‚
+ â”‚                                                         â”‚
+ â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ **Build Process:**
+ 1. &#96;vite build&#96; compiles React â†’ &#96;dist/&#96;
+ 2. Vercel serves &#96;dist/&#96; as static files
+ 3. Vercel runs &#96;api/&#96; as serverless functions
+ 4. Rewrites route all non-API requests to &#96;index.html&#96;
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Future Considerations
+ 
+ ### If Adding More Features
+ 
+ - **Search:** Add client-side search with Fuse.js or similar
+ - **More logs:** Current manifest.json approach scales to ~50 logs; beyond that, consider pagination
+ - **Comments:** Would need a backend (Supabase, Firebase, etc.)
+ 
+ ### If Performance Becomes an Issue
+ 
+ - **Large logs:** Could lazy-load log sections
+ - **WebGL:** Already GPU-accelerated; main optimization would be reducing texture size
+ - **Bundle size:** Already code-split by route; further splits possible with React.lazy
+ 
+ ### Migration Paths
+ 
+ - **To Next.js:** Move pages to &#96;app/&#96; directory, convert to RSC where beneficial
+ - **To TypeScript:** Add &#96;.tsx&#96; extensions, define interfaces for parsed data
+ 
```

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,145 @@
- 
+ # Glossary
+ 
+ &gt; Plain-English definitions for terms used in this project.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## General Terms
+ 
+ ### SPA (Single Page Application)
+ A website that loads once and updates dynamically without full page reloads. When you click a link, JavaScript swaps the content instead of fetching a new HTML page from the server.
+ 
+ ### Serverless Function
+ A small piece of code that runs on-demand on someone else&#39;s server (Vercel, AWS, etc.). You don&#39;t manage the serverâ€”it just executes when called and shuts down after. Like renting a kitchen for 10 seconds to make one sandwich.
+ 
+ ### Environment Variable
+ A secret value stored outside your code (like &#96;BUTTONDOWN_API_KEY&#96;). Never commit these to git. On Vercel, you set them in the dashboard; locally, you use a &#96;.env.local&#96; file.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## React &amp; JavaScript Terms
+ 
+ ### Component
+ A reusable piece of UI. In this project, everything from a button to an entire page is a component. Think of them like LEGO bricks that snap together.
+ 
+ ### Props
+ Data passed from a parent component to a child. Like function arguments, but for components.
+ 
+ ### State
+ Data that can change over time within a component. When state updates, React re-renders that component.
+ 
+ ### Hook
+ A function that lets you &quot;hook into&quot; React features. Common ones:
+ - &#96;useState&#96; â€“ creates state
+ - &#96;useEffect&#96; â€“ runs code when something changes
+ - &#96;useRef&#96; â€“ holds a value that doesn&#39;t trigger re-renders
+ 
+ ### JSX
+ HTML-like syntax in JavaScript files. &#96;&lt;div className=&quot;foo&quot;&gt;&#96; instead of &#96;&lt;div class=&quot;foo&quot;&gt;&#96;. React transforms it into regular JavaScript.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Build &amp; Tooling Terms
+ 
+ ### Vite
+ The build tool for this project. Handles:
+ - Development server with hot reload
+ - Bundling code for production
+ - Resolving imports
+ 
+ Pronounced &quot;veet&quot; (French for &quot;fast&quot;).
+ 
+ ### HMR (Hot Module Replacement)
+ When you save a file, only the changed module updates in the browserâ€”no full page reload. Your component state often survives edits.
+ 
+ ### Bundle
+ All your JavaScript combined into fewer files for production. Smaller bundles = faster load times.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## WebGL Terms
+ 
+ ### WebGL
+ A browser API for GPU-accelerated graphics. Think of it as Photoshop filters that run in real-time on your graphics card.
+ 
+ ### Shader
+ A small program that runs on the GPU. Two types:
+ - **Vertex shader** â€“ positions geometry
+ - **Fragment shader** â€“ colors pixels
+ 
+ In this project, the fragment shader creates the image morph effects.
+ 
+ ### Texture
+ An image loaded into GPU memory for use in shaders. The two images (&#96;luis.png&#96;, &#96;pelican.png&#96;) are textures that the shader blends.
+ 
+ ### Canvas
+ The HTML element that displays WebGL graphics. Like a TV screen that shaders paint on.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Cursor Log Terms
+ 
+ ### Slug
+ A URL-friendly identifier. For &#96;/logs/scout-cursor-log&#96;, the slug is &#96;scout-cursor-log&#96;. It matches the filename without &#96;.md&#96;.
+ 
+ ### Manifest
+ The &#96;manifest.json&#96; file that lists all available logs. Like a table of contents that the site reads to know what logs exist.
+ 
+ ### Parser
+ Code that reads text and extracts structured data. The log parser reads markdown and outputs objects with &#96;speaker&#96;, &#96;content&#96;, &#96;questions&#96;, etc.
+ 
+ ### SpecStory Format
+ An alternative export format from Cursor (via the SpecStory extension). Uses slightly different markers like &#96;_**User**_&#96; instead of &#96;**User**&#96;.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Styling Terms
+ 
+ ### Tachyons
+ A functional CSS framework where classes do one thing each. &#96;f4&#96; = font size 4, &#96;pa3&#96; = padding all 3, &#96;bg-blue&#96; = blue background. You compose styles by adding multiple classes.
+ 
+ ### Functional CSS
+ CSS where each class has a single purpose. Also called &quot;atomic CSS&quot; or &quot;utility-first CSS.&quot; Tailwind is another example (though this project uses Tachyons).
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Hosting &amp; Deployment Terms
+ 
+ ### Vercel
+ The hosting platform for this site. Handles:
+ - Serving static files
+ - Running serverless functions
+ - Automatic deploys from git
+ 
+ ### Rewrite
+ A server rule that maps one URL to another internally. In this project, all routes are rewritten to &#96;/index.html&#96; so React Router can handle them.
+ 
+ ### Edge Network / CDN
+ A global network of servers. When someone in Tokyo visits your site, they get files from a server in Asia, not your origin server in the US. Faster for everyone.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## API Terms
+ 
+ ### API Key
+ A password for an API. The Buttondown API key proves you own the newsletter. Keep it secret.
+ 
+ ### POST Request
+ An HTTP request that sends data to a server (like submitting a form). Contrast with GET, which retrieves data.
+ 
+ ### Endpoint
+ A specific URL that accepts requests. &#96;/api/subscribe&#96; is an endpoint that handles newsletter signups.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## Git Terms
+ 
+ ### Branch
+ A parallel version of your code. You can experiment on a branch without affecting &#96;main&#96;.
+ 
+ ### Commit
+ A saved snapshot of changes. Like a save point in a video game.
+ 
+ ### Merge
+ Combining one branch into another. When a feature is done, you merge it into &#96;main&#96;.
+ 
```

</details>

```diff
- ## Available Scripts
+ ## Commands
  
  | Command | Description |

- | &#96;npm run preview&#96; | Preview production build |
+ | &#96;npm run dev&#96; | Development server |

+ | &#96;npm run preview&#96; | Preview build |
  
- ## Environment Variables

- | Variable | Description | Required |

- | &#96;BUTTONDOWN_API_KEY&#96; | Buttondown newsletter API key | Yes |
- 
- ## Troubleshooting
- 
- **Log doesn&#39;t load?**
- - Check the file is in &#96;public/logs/&#96;
- - Ensure the slug matches the filename (without .md)
- - Verify &#96;manifest.json&#96; is valid JSON
- 
- **Questions not showing in sidebar?**
- - The parser looks for &#96;**User**&#96; headers
- - Ensure your export follows Cursor&#39;s format
- 
- **Code not highlighted?**
- - Code blocks need language tags: \&#96;\&#96;\&#96;javascript
- - Cursor exports handle this automatically
+ ## Tech Stack
+ 
+ React 18, Vite 5, React Router 6, WebGL, Tachyons CSS, react-markdown, Buttondown, Vercel
```

   - Excellent for content-heavy sites
   - Built-in markdown/MDX support
   - Can use React components inside Astro pages
   - Static-first with optional interactivity
   - Great SEO (pre-rendered HTML)
   - Content Collections API is perfect for blogs
   - Can migrate incrementally

   - Has MDX support
   - Static generation
   - But adds complexity they may not need

4. **Other options**:
   - Remix - good for apps, overkill for blog
   - Gatsby - historically good for blogs but Astro has kind of replaced it
   - 11ty - good but pure static, no React

Given that:
- They already have a parser for markdown (for Cursor logs)
- They use React components
- It's a personal/portfolio site
- They want a blog

I think Astro is actually the best recommendation here because:
1. It's designed for content sites like blogs
2. They can keep using React components
3. Content Collections make blog posts trivial
4. Better performance for content (islands architecture)
5. SEO benefits from static HTML

However, if they want to stay simpler and just add a basic blog to the current Vite setup, that's also possible - they could:
- Use their existing markdown parsing approach
- Store posts in public/ like they do with logs


- Create a BlogPage component similar to CursorLogPage

I'll outline two implementation approaches. For the Vite route, I'll leverage their existing markdown parsing infrastructure. The component will mirror the CursorLogPage structure, using react-markdown to render blog post content. Key steps include:
1. Create a blog posts directory in public/
2. Develop a BlogPage component with similar parsing logic
3. Add routing for individual blog post views
4. Create an index page listing available posts

The Astro approach offers more robust content management with its Collections API, allowing easier metadata handling and automatic page generation for blog posts.</details></think>

---

Great question. You have two solid paths here:

## Option 1: Stay with Vite (Simpler, but limited)

You already have the infrastructure for thisâ€”your Cursor log viewer is essentially a blog engine. You could:

```
public/
â””â”€â”€ posts/
    â”œâ”€â”€ manifest.json       # Same pattern as logs
    â”œâ”€â”€ my-first-post.md
    â””â”€â”€ another-post.md
```

**Pros:**
- No new framework to learn
- Reuse your existing markdown parser
- Keep the same deployment

**Cons:**
- No static generation (bad for SEOâ€”Google sees a loading spinner before content)
- No build-time syntax highlighting
- Manual frontmatter parsing
- You're essentially building your own blog engine

---

## Option 2: Astro (Recommended for a real blog)

Astro is purpose-built for content sites. Here's why it's worth the switch:

| Feature | Vite + React | Astro |
|---------|--------------|-------|
| Markdown blog posts | Manual parsing | Built-in Content Collections |
| SEO | Poor (client-rendered) | Great (static HTML) |
| Keep React components | âœ… | âœ… (via `@astrojs/react`) |
| Performance | Good | Excellent (ships 0 JS by default) |
| Frontmatter/metadata | DIY | Built-in with type safety |

### What Migration Would Look Like

Astro can consume your existing React components:

```astro
---
// src/pages/index.astro
import { WebGLMorpher } from '../components/WebGLMorpher';
import { NewsletterSignup } from '../components/NewsletterSignup';
---

<html>
  <body>
    <!-- Static content renders as HTML -->
    <h1>Luis Queral</h1>
    
    <!-- React components load with client:load -->
    <WebGLMorpher client:load />
    <NewsletterSignup client:load />
  </body>
</html>
```

### Blog Posts Become Trivial

```
src/
â””â”€â”€ content/
    â””â”€â”€ blog/
        â”œâ”€â”€ my-first-post.md
        â””â”€â”€ another-post.md
```

Each post is just:

```markdown
---
title: "My First Post"
date: 2025-12-01
tags: ["design", "code"]
---

Your content here with **markdown** and `code`.
```

Astro auto-generates:
- Type-safe frontmatter validation
- RSS feed
- Sitemap
- Static HTML pages

---

## My Recommendation

**If you're serious about blogging:** Switch to Astro. The migration isn't painful because:
1. Your React components work with minimal changes
2. Your CSS files transfer directly
3. Astro's learning curve is gentle (it's mostly HTML + markdown)

**If you just want 2-3 posts occasionally:** Stay with Vite and extend your log viewer pattern. Less optimal but less work.

---

Want me to sketch out what an Astro migration would look like for your project? Or show you how to extend the current Vite setup with a quick blog feature?

Good, I've reviewed everything. Here's the migration plan:

---

# Astro Migration Plan

## Current State

```
/                    â†’ HomePage.jsx (React with WebGL, Newsletter)
/logs/:slug          â†’ CursorLogPage.jsx (fetches markdown, parses, renders)
/api/subscribe       â†’ Vercel serverless function
```

**Interactive components:** WebGLMorpher, NewsletterSignup (need `client:load`)  
**Static-friendly:** Most of the homepage text, log content

---

## Target State

```
/                    â†’ src/pages/index.astro
/logs/[slug]         â†’ src/pages/logs/[slug].astro
/blog                â†’ src/pages/blog/index.astro (new!)
/blog/[slug]         â†’ src/pages/blog/[...slug].astro (new!)
/api/subscribe       â†’ Keep as Vercel function OR move to Astro API route
```

---

## Migration Phases

### Phase 1: Install & Configure Astro
- Install `astro`, `@astrojs/react`, `@astrojs/vercel`
- Create `astro.config.mjs`
- Update `package.json` scripts
- Keep existing React componentsâ€”they'll work inside Astro

### Phase 2: Create Base Layout
- `src/layouts/BaseLayout.astro` â€“ HTML shell, global styles
- Import Tachyons and custom CSS

### Phase 3: Migrate Homepage
- `src/pages/index.astro` â€“ static HTML for text
- Import `WebGLMorpher` and `NewsletterSignup` with `client:load`
- Random take logic moves to Astro frontmatter (picks at build time) or stays in a small React component

### Phase 4: Migrate Cursor Logs
Two options:
- **Option A:** Keep as React page with `client:only` (quickest)
- **Option B:** Convert to Content Collection (better, Astro renders markdown at build time)

I recommend **Option B** â€“ your logs become first-class content with better SEO.

### Phase 5: Add Blog with Content Collections
- `src/content/config.ts` â€“ define blog schema
- `src/content/blog/` â€“ markdown posts go here
- `src/pages/blog/index.astro` â€“ post listing
- `src/pages/blog/[...slug].astro` â€“ individual posts

### Phase 6: Clean Up
- Remove `vite.config.js`
- Remove `react-router-dom` (Astro handles routing)
- Remove `src/App.jsx`, `src/main.jsx`
- Update `vercel.json` for Astro output

---

## File Structure After Migration

```
â”œâ”€â”€ astro.config.mjs              # Astro config (replaces vite.config.js)
â”œâ”€â”€ src/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ layouts/
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ BaseLayout.astro      # HTML wrapper
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ pages/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.astro           # Homepage
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ blog/
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.astro       # Blog listing
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [...slug].astro   # Blog post page
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ logs/
â”‚   â”‚       â””â”€â”€ [slug].astro      # Cursor log page
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ content/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ config.ts             # Content schemas
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ blog/                 # Blog posts (markdown)
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ logs/                 # Cursor logs (moved from public/)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ components/               # Keep existing React components
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ WebGLMorpher.jsx
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ NewsletterSignup.jsx
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ CursorLog/            # May simplify to Astro components
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ styles/                   # Keep existing CSS

â””â”€â”€ package.json
```

## What Stays the Same

| Item | Status |
|------|--------|
| `WebGLMorpher.jsx` | Keep (use with `client:load`) |

```diff
+ # Hello World
+ 
+ This is the first post on the newly rebuilt site, now powered by [Astro](https://astro.build/).
+ 
+ ## Why Astro?
+ 
+ Astro is perfect for content-heavy sites because it:
+ 
+ - Ships **zero JavaScript by default** (faster pages)
+ - Has built-in **Content Collections** for managing posts
+ - Lets you use **React components** where needed
+ - Generates **static HTML** for great SEO
+ 
+ ## What&#39;s Next
+ 
+ I&#39;ll be adding more posts about:
+ 
+ - Design systems and tooling
+ - Creative coding experiments
+ - Product design thoughts
```

## Migration Complete âœ…

### What Changed

| Before (Vite + React) | After (Astro) |
|----------------------|---------------|
| `vite.config.js` | `astro.config.mjs` |
| React Router (`App.jsx`) | File-based routing (`src/pages/`) |
| Manual markdown parsing | Content Collections |
| Client-rendered | Static HTML + React islands |

### New Structure

```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ content/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ config.ts          # Schema definitions
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ blog/              # Blog posts
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ hello-world.md
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ logs/              # Cursor logs
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ scout-cursor-log.md
â”‚       â””â”€â”€ scout-cursor-log-2.md
â”œâ”€â”€ layouts/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ BaseLayout.astro
â”œâ”€â”€ pages/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.astro        # Homepage
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ blog/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.astro    # /blog
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [...slug].astro # /blog/post-name
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ logs/
â”‚       â””â”€â”€ [slug].astro   # /logs/log-name
â””â”€â”€ components/
    â”œâ”€â”€ WebGLMorpher.jsx   # Kept (client:load)
    â””â”€â”€ NewsletterSignup.jsx # Kept (client:load)
```

### Routes

- `/` â†’ Homepage with WebGL morpher
- `/blog` â†’ Blog listing
- `/blog/hello-world` â†’ Sample blog post
- `/logs/scout-cursor-log` â†’ Cursor log viewer

<details><summary>Tool use: **code_edit** â€¢ Edit file: /Users/luisqueral/Projects/studio-queral-2026/src/content/blog/on-design-systems.md</summary>

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 30, lines removed: 1

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,30 @@
- 
+ ---
+ title: &quot;On Design Systems&quot;
+ description: &quot;Why consistency matters more than perfection&quot;
+ date: 2025-11-28
+ tags: [&quot;design&quot;, &quot;systems&quot;, &quot;product&quot;]
+ draft: false
+ ---
+ 
+ A design system isn&#39;t a component library. It&#39;s a shared language.
+ 
+ ## The Problem
+ 
+ Every team I&#39;ve worked with has faced the same challenge: as products grow, inconsistency creeps in. Not because anyone is careless, but because context is lost. The button that was blue in 2021 becomes teal in 2023 because someone didn&#39;t know the original decision existed.
+ 
+ ## What Actually Works
+ 
+ The best design systems I&#39;ve seen share a few traits:
+ 
+ 1. **They document the *why*, not just the *what*.** A color isn&#39;t just &#96;#357edd&#96;. It&#39;s &quot;our primary action color, chosen for accessibility against white backgrounds.&quot;
+ 
+ 2. **They&#39;re discoverable.** If a designer has to ask where something is, the system has failed.
+ 
+ 3. **They evolve.** A system that can&#39;t change becomes a cage.
+ 
+ ## The Uncomfortable Truth
+ 
+ You don&#39;t need a design system until you do. And by the time you realize you need one, you&#39;re already dealing with the debt.
+ 
+ Start small. Document decisions as you make them. The system will emerge.
+ 
```

</details>

</tool-use>

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,37 @@
- 
+ ---
+ title: &quot;Tools for Thinking&quot;
+ description: &quot;The software I actually use every day&quot;
+ date: 2025-11-15
+ tags: [&quot;tools&quot;, &quot;productivity&quot;, &quot;workflow&quot;]
+ draft: false
+ ---
+ 
+ People ask about my setup. Here&#39;s what&#39;s actually on my dock.
+ 
+ ## For Writing
+ 
+ **Obsidian** for notes and thinking. I&#39;ve tried Notion, Roam, Logseq, and a dozen others. Obsidian wins because:
+ - Local markdown files I actually own
+ - Fast enough that I don&#39;t notice it
+ - Plugins when I need them, invisible when I don&#39;t
+ 
+ **iA Writer** for long-form. When I need to focus on just the words.
+ 
+ ## For Design
+ 
+ **Figma** obviously. But increasingly, I sketch in code first. The feedback loop is faster.
+ 
+ ## For Code
+ 
+ **Cursor** has replaced VS Code for me. The AI assistance isn&#39;t magic, but it removes enough friction that I think differently about what&#39;s worth building.
+ 
+ **Warp** for terminal. The AI features are fine, but the real win is that it just feels modern.
+ 
+ ## What I&#39;ve Stopped Using
+ 
+ - Slack (async is better)
+ - Most task managers (a text file works)
+ - Read-later apps (I was just hoarding)
+ 
+ The best tool is the one you&#39;ll actually use.
+ 
```

</details>

</tool-use>

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,46 @@
- 
+ ---
+ title: &quot;Creative Coding for Designers&quot;
+ description: &quot;You don&#39;t need to be a programmer to make generative art&quot;
+ date: 2025-10-22
+ tags: [&quot;creative-coding&quot;, &quot;generative&quot;, &quot;art&quot;]
+ draft: false
+ ---
+ 
+ I learned to code because I wanted to make things I couldn&#39;t make in Photoshop.
+ 
+ ## The Myth
+ 
+ There&#39;s this idea that creative coding requires years of programming experience. That you need to understand algorithms and data structures before you can make anything interesting.
+ 
+ This is wrong.
+ 
+ ## What You Actually Need
+ 
+ **30 minutes with p5.js.** That&#39;s it. Open the [web editor](https://editor.p5js.org/), type this:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;javascript
+ function setup() {
+   createCanvas(400, 400);
+ }
+ 
+ function draw() {
+   circle(mouseX, mouseY, 50);
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ You just made interactive art. The circle follows your mouse.
+ 
+ ## Why It Matters for Designers
+ 
+ Creative coding teaches you to think in systems. Instead of designing one screen, you design the rules that generate screens. Instead of choosing one color, you define the relationships between colors.
+ 
+ This mindset transfers directly to design systems work.
+ 
+ ## Resources That Actually Help
+ 
+ - **[The Coding Train](https://thecodingtrain.com/)** â€“ Daniel Shiffman makes everything approachable
+ - **[Generative Design](http://www.generative-gestaltung.de/)** â€“ The book that got me started
+ - **[Observable](https://observablehq.com/)** â€“ See how others think in code
+ 
+ Don&#39;t wait until you feel ready. Make something ugly today.
+ 
```

<details><summary>Tool use: **code_edit** â€¢ Edit file: /Users/luisqueral/Projects/studio-queral-2026/src/content/blog/data-synth.md</summary>

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 63, lines removed: 1

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,63 @@
- 
+ ---
+ title: &quot;DataSynth: Turn Any Dataset Into Sound&quot;
+ description: &quot;A client-side data sonification tool that transforms JSON, CSV, and GeoJSON into audio&quot;
+ date: 2025-11-20
+ tags: [&quot;creative-coding&quot;, &quot;audio&quot;, &quot;data-viz&quot;, &quot;javascript&quot;]
+ draft: false
+ ---
+ 
+ I built [DataSynth](https://datasynth.vercel.app) because I wanted to *hear* data, not just see it.
+ 
+ ## What It Does
+ 
+ DataSynth takes any datasetâ€”earthquake magnitudes, exoplanet masses, stock pricesâ€”and maps it to sound. Bigger earthquakes become lower pitches. Distant planets get more reverb. You hear patterns that charts might miss.
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ Data Field          â†’    Audio Parameter
+ â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
+ earthquake.magnitude  â†’  frequency (pitch)
+ earthquake.depth      â†’  filter cutoff
+ earthquake.latitude   â†’  stereo pan
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ## Why Sonification?
+ 
+ Visualization has limits. Our eyes track ~10-15 data points before confusion sets in. But our ears can parse hundreds of simultaneous audio eventsâ€”think of how easily you follow a conversation in a crowded room.
+ 
+ Sonification works especially well for:
+ - **Time series data** (hear trends as melodies)
+ - **Multi-dimensional data** (map dimensions to pitch, pan, effects)
+ - **Anomaly detection** (unusual data points *sound* wrong)
+ 
+ ## The Tech Stack
+ 
+ I intentionally kept this framework-free:
+ 
+ | Technology | Purpose |
+ |------------|---------|
+ | Vanilla JS + ES6 Modules | No build step needed |
+ | Web Audio API | Native browser synthesis |
+ | D3.js | Node graph visualization |
+ | Tachyons CSS | Utility-first styling |
+ 
+ The whole thing is ~2000 lines of modular JavaScript. No React, no bundler, no npm install. Just open &#96;index.html&#96; and go.
+ 
+ ## How It Works
+ 
+ The architecture follows a clean pipeline:
+ 
+ 1. **Data Processor** â€” Parses JSON/CSV, finds interesting fields
+ 2. **Parameter Mapper** â€” Analyzes variance, suggests optimal mappings
+ 3. **Audio Engine** â€” 10 waveform types, real-time effects chain
+ 4. **Patch Viz** â€” D3-powered node graph showing dataâ†’audio flow
+ 
+ The mapper is the interesting part. It doesn&#39;t just randomly assign fields to parametersâ€”it analyzes each field&#39;s variance, uniqueness, and range, then suggests which audio parameters would best represent it.
+ 
+ ## Try It
+ 
+ **Live demo:** [datasynth.vercel.app](https://datasynth.vercel.app)
+ 
+ **Source:** [github.com/luismqueral/data-synth](https://github.com/luismqueral/data-synth)
+ 
+ Load the USGS earthquake feed and hit play. You&#39;ll hear a week of global seismic activity in about 30 seconds. It&#39;s strangely meditative.
+ 
```

```
![illustration](_app/mtk.png)

**Media Tool Kit** is [my personal framework](http://www.queral.studio) for media manipulation. It&#39;s designed for LLM&#39;s within generative coding environments to make modifications to images, sounds, and video quickly and consistently.

The idea is to quickly make edits to media by just asking it.

&quot;Compress this video to 10MB&quot; or &quot;Remove transparency&quot;. That kind of stuff.

## Tools Used
This is python-centric workspace. Scripts created in this workspace will leverage the following frameworks.
- **Video**: ffmpeg
- **Image**: ImageMagick  
- **Audio**: SoX (Sound eXchange)

I expect this list to grow over time, but for now this will do.

## Installation

### macOS (Homebrew)
&#96;&#96;&#96;bash
brew install ffmpeg imagemagick sox python3
&#96;&#96;&#96;

### Ubuntu/Debian
&#96;&#96;&#96;bash
sudo apt update
sudo apt install ffmpeg imagemagick sox python3 python3-pip
&#96;&#96;&#96;

### Verify Installation
&#96;&#96;&#96;bash
ffmpeg -version
convert -version
sox --version
python3 --version
&#96;&#96;&#96;

## Structure

&#96;&#96;&#96;
media-tool-kit/
â”œâ”€â”€ projects/       # Individual media processing projects
â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/        # Reusable utility scripts
â”œâ”€â”€ .cursor/rules/  # Cursor IDE rules and guidelines
â””â”€â”€ README.md
&#96;&#96;&#96;

## Workflow

1. Drop media files into the root or describe what you need
2. AI assistant creates organized project folder in &#96;projects/&#96;
3. Processing happens with clear logging
4. Results saved to project&#39;s &#96;output/&#96; directory
5. Commands logged for reproducibility

### Project Structure

Each new project should be listed in the &#96;projects/&#96; directory and carry a consistent structure:

&#96;&#96;&#96;
projects/
â””â”€â”€ [project-name]/
    â”œâ”€â”€ input/          # Source/original files
    â”œâ”€â”€ output/         # Processed results
    â””â”€â”€ README.md       # What was done, commands used
&#96;&#96;&#96;

This keeps work organized, originals safe, and makes it easy to reproduce or reference past work.

## Getting Started

Just describe what you want to do with your media files. Examples:

- &quot;Convert all these images to PNG&quot;
- &quot;Extract audio from this video and normalize it&quot;
- &quot;Trim this video from 1:30 to 2:45&quot;


```
</details>
</tool-use>

```diff
+ 
+ ## The Idea
+ 
+ Instead of memorizing arcane command-line arguments, just describe what you want:
+ 
+ - *&quot;Compress this video to 10MB&quot;*
+ - *&quot;Remove transparency from these PNGs&quot;*
+ - *&quot;Extract audio and normalize it&quot;*
+ - *&quot;Trim from 1:30 to 2:45&quot;*
+ 
+ The AI figures out the right incantations. You get your media processed.
+ 
+ ## What&#39;s Under the Hood
+ 
+ Media Tool Kit is a Python-centric workspace that wraps three battle-tested tools:
+ 
+ | Tool | Purpose |
+ |------|---------|
+ | **ffmpeg** | Video processing |
+ | **ImageMagick** | Image manipulation |
+ | **SoX** | Audio processing |
+ 
+ These aren&#39;t trendy librariesâ€”they&#39;re the same tools professionals have used for decades. Reliable, fast, well-documented.
  
  ## How It Works
  
- *[Brief technical overview]*
- 
- ## Try It
+ The structure is intentionally simple:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ media-tool-kit/
+ â”œâ”€â”€ projects/       # Individual processing jobs
+ â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/        # Reusable utilities
+ â”œâ”€â”€ .cursor/rules/  # AI context and guidelines
+ â””â”€â”€ README.md
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ Each project gets its own folder with &#96;input/&#96;, &#96;output/&#96;, and a README documenting what was done. Originals stay safe. Everything is reproducible.
+ 
+ ## Why This Exists
+ 
+ Every creative technologist eventually builds something like this. You&#39;re editing a video, need to export a gif, and suddenly you&#39;re 15 browser tabs deep in Stack Overflow trying to remember the ffmpeg palette filter syntax.
+ 
+ Now I just describe what I need. The AI handles the translation.
  
  **Source:** [github.com/luismqueral/media-tool-kit](https://github.com/luismqueral/media-tool-kit)
```

```
# Media Tool Kit - Cursor Rules

## Project Purpose
This repository is designed for rapid media file manipulation (video, audio, images) using LLMs and generative IDEs. Keep solutions practical, direct, and focused on getting media processing done efficiently.

## Core Principles
- **Modular over monolithic** - Create focused, reusable scripts rather than complex frameworks
- **Direct tool usage** - Leverage industry-standard tools directly (ffmpeg, ImageMagick, SoX)
- **Keep it clean** - Organize work into projects, don&#39;t clutter the root directory
- **Preserve originals** - Never modify source files in place unless explicitly requested

## Language &amp; Tools

### Primary Language: Python
- Use Python 3.8+ for all scripts and utilities
- Keep external dependencies minimal - prefer subprocess calls to tools over heavy wrappers
- Use standard library where possible (subprocess, pathlib, argparse, logging)
- Only add dependencies when they provide clear value (e.g., &#96;ffmpeg-python&#96; for complex pipelines)

### Required Command-Line Tools
- **Video**: &#96;ffmpeg&#96; (primary tool for all video operations)
- **Image**: &#96;ImageMagick&#96; (convert, mogrify, composite, etc.)
- **Audio**: &#96;SoX&#96; (Sound eXchange - audio processing Swiss Army knife)

### Tool Usage Philosophy
- Prefer direct command-line calls via subprocess for transparency
- Show the actual commands being run (helps with debugging and learning)
- Log operations so work is reproducible
- Provide both script solutions AND raw commands when helpful

## Workspace Organization

### When User Drops Files in Root
1. Assess what they want to do
2. Create a descriptive project folder in &#96;projects/&#96; (e.g., &#96;projects/2024-11-13-video-compression/&#96;)
3. Move or reference files appropriately
4. Do the work within that project structure
5. Keep root clean

### Project Structure (Auto-Create as Needed)
&#96;&#96;&#96;
projects/
â””â”€â”€ [descriptive-name]/
    â”œâ”€â”€ input/          # Original files (or symlinks)
    â”œâ”€â”€ output/         # Processed results
    â””â”€â”€ README.md       # What was done, commands used
&#96;&#96;&#96;

### Scripts Directory
- Place reusable utilities in &#96;scripts/&#96; ONLY after a pattern emerges
- Name clearly: &#96;compress_video.py&#96;, &#96;batch_resize_images.py&#96;, etc.
- Include usage examples in docstrings
- Keep scripts standalone when possible (can be run independently)

**When to create a script in &#96;scripts/&#96;:**
- âœ“ Operation done 2-3+ times with similar parameters
- âœ“ Complex multi-step process that&#39;s likely to repeat
- âœ“ Something that would benefit other projects
- âœ“ User explicitly asks for a reusable tool

**When NOT to create a script in &#96;scripts/&#96;:**
- âœ— First time doing an operation (just use commands directly)
- âœ— Highly specific one-off task
- âœ— Simple one-liner that&#39;s easy to remember/modify
- âœ— &quot;Just in case&quot; utilities that might never be used

**Project-specific scripts:**
- One-off or experimental scripts can live in the project folder itself
- If a project-specific script proves useful, promote it to &#96;scripts/&#96; later
- No shame in copying/pasting commands between projects - refactor when the need is clear

## Workflow Guidelines

### File Handling
- **Input files**: Keep originals safe, work on copies or write to separate output directories
- **Naming**: Use clear, descriptive names for outputs (include dimensions, codec, bitrate, etc.)
- **Formats**: Preserve format unless conversion is the goal
- **Permissions**: Check file accessibility before processing

### Processing Approach
1. **Understand the ask** - What operation(s) are needed?
2. **Validate inputs** - Check files exist, formats are supported
3. **Show the plan** - Briefly explain what will happen
4. **Execute** - Run the operations with clear progress/logging
5. **Verify** - Confirm outputs were created successfully
6. **Report** - Summarize what was done and where outputs are

### Script Creation Philosophy
Follow the &quot;Rule of Three&quot; - don&#39;t abstract until you&#39;ve done it three times:

**First time**: Use direct commands in project folder, document in README
&#96;&#96;&#96;bash
# Just run the command, log it
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vf &quot;scale=1280:720&quot; output.mp4
&#96;&#96;&#96;

**Second time**: Maybe copy/paste from previous project, adjust parameters
&#96;&#96;&#96;bash
# Still fine to just use commands with different params
ffmpeg -i video2.mp4 -vf &quot;scale=1280:720&quot; output2.mp4
&#96;&#96;&#96;

**Third time**: Now consider making a reusable script
&#96;&#96;&#96;python
# scripts/resize_video.py - now it&#39;s worth abstracting
def resize_video(input_path, output_path, width, height):
    ...
&#96;&#96;&#96;

This keeps you from building tools you don&#39;t need while ensuring truly useful patterns get captured.

### Error Handling
- Always check if required tools (ffmpeg, convert, sox) are available
- Validate file paths before processing
- Catch and explain errors clearly
- Suggest fixes when operations fail

### Documentation
- Log operations in project README files
- Include the actual commands used (for reproducibility)
- Note any quality/size trade-offs made
- Keep logs concise but informative

## Common Operations Reference

### Video (ffmpeg)
&#96;&#96;&#96;bash
# Compress video
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vcodec libx264 -crf 23 output.mp4

# Trim video
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -ss 00:00:10 -to 00:00:20 -c copy output.mp4

# Extract audio
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vn -acodec copy audio.aac

# Convert format
ffmpeg -i input.mov -c:v copy -c:a copy output.mp4
&#96;&#96;&#96;

### Image (ImageMagick)
&#96;&#96;&#96;bash
# Resize image
convert input.jpg -resize 1920x1080 output.jpg

# Batch convert format
mogrify -format png *.jpg

# Add watermark
composite -gravity southeast watermark.png input.jpg output.jpg

# Compress
convert input.jpg -quality 85 output.jpg
&#96;&#96;&#96;

### Audio (SoX)
&#96;&#96;&#96;bash
# Convert format
sox input.wav output.mp3

# Trim audio
sox input.mp3 output.mp3 trim 10 20

# Normalize volume
sox input.mp3 output.mp3 norm

# Change sample rate
sox input.wav -r 44100 output.wav
&#96;&#96;&#96;

## Code Style

### Python Scripts
- Use &#96;pathlib.Path&#96; for file operations
- Include &#96;if __name__ == &quot;__main__&quot;&#96; blocks
- Add argparse for CLI arguments when scripts are reusable
- Use f-strings for formatting
- Type hints appreciated but not required

### Script Template
&#96;&#96;&#96;python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
&quot;&quot;&quot;
Brief description of what this script does.
&quot;&quot;&quot;
import subprocess
from pathlib import Path

def main():
    # Your logic here
    pass

if __name__ == &quot;__main__&quot;:
    main()
&#96;&#96;&#96;

## Dependencies Management
- Keep a &#96;requirements.txt&#96; in the root for any Python packages
- Document tool installation in README (brew, apt, etc.)
- Assume common tools may not be installed - check and warn

```

```diff
+ ## The Secret Sauce: Cursor Rules
+ 
+ The real power isn&#39;t in the scriptsâ€”it&#39;s in the &#96;.cursor/rules/&#96; file that teaches the AI how to work within this environment. The rules establish:
+ 
+ **Core Principles:**
+ - Modular over monolithic â€” focused, reusable scripts rather than complex frameworks
+ - Direct tool usage â€” leverage ffmpeg, ImageMagick, SoX directly
+ - Keep it clean â€” organize work into projects, don&#39;t clutter the root
+ - Preserve originals â€” never modify source files in place
+ 
+ **The &quot;Rule of Three&quot;:**
+ 
+ Don&#39;t abstract until you&#39;ve done something three times:
+ 
+ 1. **First time:** Just run the command, document in README
+ 2. **Second time:** Copy/paste from previous project, adjust params
+ 3. **Third time:** Now make a reusable script
+ 
+ This prevents over-engineering while capturing truly useful patterns.
+ 
+ **Automatic Project Organization:**
+ 
+ When I drop files in the root, the AI:
+ 1. Assesses what I want to do
+ 2. Creates a descriptive project folder in &#96;projects/&#96;
+ 3. Sets up &#96;input/&#96; and &#96;output/&#96; directories
+ 4. Does the work within that structure
+ 5. Logs commands in a README for reproducibility
  
  ## Tools Used
  
- This is a Python-centric workspace. Scripts leverage three battle-tested frameworks:
- 
- - **Video**: ffmpeg
- - **Image**: ImageMagick  
- - **Audio**: SoX (Sound eXchange)
- 
- I expect this list to grow over time, but for now this will do.
+ This is a Python-centric workspace leveraging three battle-tested tools:
+ 
+ | Tool | Purpose |
+ |------|---------|
+ | **ffmpeg** | Video processing |
+ | **ImageMagick** | Image manipulation |
+ | **SoX** | Audio processing (the &quot;Swiss Army knife&quot; of audio) |
+ 
+ The rules include a reference of common operations for eachâ€”compress video, trim audio, batch resize imagesâ€”so the AI doesn&#39;t have to figure out the syntax each time.
  
  ## Structure
  
  &#96;&#96;&#96;
  media-tool-kit/
- â”œâ”€â”€ projects/       # Individual media processing projects
- â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/        # Reusable utility scripts
- â”œâ”€â”€ .cursor/rules/  # Cursor IDE rules and guidelines
+ â”œâ”€â”€ projects/           # Individual media processing projects
+ â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [project-name]/
+ â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ input/      # Original files
+ â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ output/     # Processed results
+ â”‚       â””â”€â”€ README.md   # Commands used, notes
+ â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/            # Reusable utilities (when patterns emerge)
+ â”œâ”€â”€ .cursor/rules/      # The AI&#39;s playbook
  â””â”€â”€ README.md
  &#96;&#96;&#96;
  
- ## Workflow
- 
- 1. Drop media files into the root or describe what you need
- 2. AI assistant creates organized project folder in &#96;projects/&#96;
- 3. Processing happens with clear logging
- 4. Results saved to project&#39;s &#96;output/&#96; directory
- 5. Commands logged for reproducibility

- ### Project Structure

- Each new project gets its own folder with a consistent structure:
- 
- &#96;&#96;&#96;
- projects/
- â””â”€â”€ [project-name]/

-     â”œâ”€â”€ output/         # Processed results

-

- 
- ## Getting Started
- 
- Just describe what you want to do with your media files:
- 
- - &quot;Convert all these images to PNG&quot;
- - &quot;Extract audio from this video and normalize it&quot;
- - &quot;Trim this video from 1:30 to 2:45&quot;
+ ## Why This Approach Works
+ 
+ Most &quot;AI coding&quot; demos show you generating a React app. But the real productivity wins are in boring automationâ€”the tedious tasks you do regularly but never bother scripting.
+ 
+ By encoding my preferences and workflow into Cursor rules, I&#39;ve essentially trained a media processing assistant that:
+ 
+ - Knows my file organization preferences
+ - Uses the right tools for each job
+ - Documents everything for reproducibility
+ - Doesn&#39;t over-engineer solutions
+ 
+ It&#39;s less &quot;AI writing code&quot; and more &quot;AI following my playbook.&quot;
```

```diff
+ ![Jump City Records](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/luismqueral/jumpcityrecords/master/_assets/jump-city.png)
+ 
+ [Jump City Records](https://github.com/luismqueral/jumpcityrecords) is an experimental, open-source record label that produces and releases its albums through a series of Python bots. I designed it and [Michiel Overtoom](http://www.michielovertoom.com/) engineered it.
+ 
+ The illustration above was done by [Matt Carignan](http://mattcarignan.com/).
+ 
+ ## How It Works
+ 
+ When the script runs, it randomly assigns:
+ 
+ - **Album title** â€” pulled from random Wikipedia article titles
+ - **Number of tracks** â€” between 3-8
+ - **Track titles** â€” also from Wikipedia (*&quot;Yuuka Maeda&quot;*, *&quot;Tartu Town Hall&quot;*)
+ - **Track durations** â€” 15 seconds to 6 minutes each
+ 
+ The audio is entirely sample-based. Samples come from field recordings, avant-garde albums, and other sourcesâ€”mostly downloaded from archive.org. The script selects a folder, grabs three random audio samples, layers them in SoX, applies a chain of effects, and exports the master as FLAC.

+ ## Example Output
+

+ â–‘ jump city records, Jim Brigden (2015-01-14 17.24.14)
```

```diff
+ ---
+ title: &quot;Strategy Cards for Creative Thinking&quot;

+ 
+ I&#39;ve been collecting creative thinking promptsâ€”strategies that help approach design challenges from unexpected angles. Each offers a different lens through which to view a problem.
+ 
+ ## How to Use Them
+ 
+ Pick a strategy that feels relevant (or deliberately irrelevant) to your current challenge:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ I&#39;m working on [describe your project briefly]. 
+ 
+ Please apply the &quot;Honor the Shadows&quot; strategy to help me 
+ think about this differently.
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ Or try random selection for broader exploration:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ Select 5 random strategies and apply each one to 
+ [describe your project]. Give me distinct perspectives 
+ on how to approach this challenge.
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ## Some Favorites
+ 
+ ### Honor the Shadows
+ *Theme: Psychology*
+ 
+ &gt; What exists in the shadows of this project, unacknowledged? Identify the overlooked aspects, the negative spaces, or the deliberately ignored elements. Sometimes the most profound insights are found not in the light, but in what we&#39;ve chosen to leave in the dark.
+ 
+ ### Follow the Resistance
+ *Theme: Philosophy*
+ 
+ &gt; Where do you feel resistance, friction, or difficulty? Instead of overcoming these, follow them deliberately. What happens when you move *toward* what resists you?
+ 
+ ### Break the Container
+ *Theme: Philosophy*
+ 
+ &gt; What invisible containersâ€”assumptions, frameworks, boundariesâ€”currently hold this work? Identify them precisely. Then, deliberately shatter at least one. What spills out?
+ 
+ ### Excavate the Palimpsest
+ *Theme: History*
+ 
+ &gt; Approach this situation as a palimpsestâ€”a manuscript with layers of text written, erased, and overwritten across time. What earlier inscriptions remain partially visible beneath current narratives?
+ 
+ ### Apply Quantum Tunneling
+ *Theme: Science*
+ 
+ &gt; Consider this through quantum tunneling: particles passing through impenetrable barriers. What supposedly insurmountable obstacles might be traversed by probability, not force?
+ 
+ ### Invoke Dadaist Disruption
+ *Theme: Art*
+ 
+ &gt; Apply Dadaist principles. What happens when you deliberately introduce chaos, absurdity, or anti-logic into the process?
+ 
+ ## The Full Collection
+ 
+ The complete set includes strategies drawn from:
+ 
+ - **Psychology** â€” Shadow work, resistance, cognitive reframing
+ - **History** â€” Phoenician trading, Ottoman governance, Hanseatic cooperation
+ - **Science** â€” Quantum mechanics, systems thinking, emergence
+ - **Philosophy** â€” Stoicism, Zen, phenomenology
+ - **Art** â€” Dadaism, minimalism, found objects
+ 
+ **Source:** [studio-queral-context/misc/strategies.md](https://github.com/luismqueral/studio-queral-context/blob/main/misc/strategies.md)
```

```
# -*- coding: utf8 -*-

&quot;&quot;&quot;
jumpcity.py

Main driver. Software by Michiel Overtoom, motoom@xs4all.nl
&quot;&quot;&quot;

import albumart
import albumtracks
import composetrack
import os
import codecs
import constants
import datetime
&quot;&quot;&quot; If you want automatical uploading to SoundCloud using scaup,
you have to place &#39;scaup.py&#39; (and &#39;credentials.py&#39;) in the same
directory as &#39;jumpcity.py&#39;. See: https://github.com/motoom/scaup &quot;&quot;&quot;
try:
    import scaup
    scaup_available = True
except ImportError:
    scaup_available = False


def generatealbum():
    &quot;&quot;&quot; Generate a complete album. &quot;&quot;&quot;
    longstring = &quot;&quot;&quot;\
     ____________        _..._
     | ________ |  ___ .&#39;     &#96;. ____________
     ||        || |   /&#96;.  .-&#39;  \            |
     ||        || |  ( O / O.   &quot;\           |
     ||        || |   | (_)     _/           |
     ||________|| |   /((())) / \_____       |
     |        ] | |   \______/  //    \      |
     |          | |   _..-)    //      \     |
     |          | |  / .\\_..-&#39; \       \    |
     |          | |_/    \       &#96;.      \___|
     |          |  /     |         \     /
_____|__________| /      /         /    / _______
                  |    ./|        /    /
                 _|____\_|        |   /
                 \       /       _)   \__
                  \     /       (_\    \()
               ___|_____|____  / / \\_\/
            __/           |  |/ /___|
    ..&#39;&#96;..&#39;|  |           | _/_/    |       
  .&#39;(( ((( |__|           |(__()    |
.&#39;((( ((( .&#39;__|           |  |______|________
 ((( (( ((&#96;.  |           |  |              /
(((((  (((((&#96;.|           |  |             /
  ((( ((( ((.&#39;|           | /             /
&#96;..-&#39;&#39;-....&#39;  |___________|/             /
    &quot;&quot;&quot;
    print &quot;\n&quot; + longstring
    print &quot;\x1b[1m&quot; + &quot;[ jump city records ]&quot; 
    print &quot; â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢&quot;
    # Start with the name and release date.
    at = albumtracks.AlbumTracks()
    while True:
        albumname, datestamp, tracks = at.generatealbum()
        safestamp = datestamp.replace(&quot; / &quot;, &quot; &quot;).replace(&quot;:&quot;, &quot;.&quot;) # Most filesystems don&#39;t like / and : in filenames.
        stampedname = u&quot;%s (%s)&quot; % (albumname, safestamp)
        albumdir = os.path.join(&quot;..&quot;, &quot;_albums&quot;, stampedname)
        if os.path.exists(albumdir): # Don&#39;t overwrite existing albums with the same name.
            continue
        break
    print &quot;\x1b[1m&quot; + &quot;\x1b[7m&quot; + &quot;\nMaking new album &#39;%s&#39;&quot; % stampedname + &quot;\x1b[0m&quot;
    os.mkdir(albumdir)

    # A nice picture...
    picturefilename = albumart.rendertopng(albumname, datestamp, albumdir)
    
    # Make a description of the entire album - this is added as a comment to every track in the album.
    description = [
        u&quot;â–‘ jump city records, %s&quot; % stampedname,
        u&quot;â–‘ generated by jumpcity.py&quot;,
        u&quot;&quot;,
        u&quot;â–‘ (https://github.com/luismqueral/jumpcityrecords)&quot;,
        u&quot;&quot;,
        ]
    maxtracknamelen = max(len(track[0]) for track in tracks)
    for nr, track in enumerate(tracks):
        trackname, duration = track
        minutes = int(duration / 60)
        seconds = duration - minutes * 60
        padspace = &quot; &quot; if minutes &lt; 10 else &quot;&quot;
        line = u&quot;%02d %-*s %s%d:%02d&quot; % (nr + 1, maxtracknamelen, trackname, padspace, minutes, seconds)
        description.append(line)
    description.extend([
        u&quot;a project by:&quot;,
        u&quot; â€¢ Michiel Overtoom (http://www.michielovertoom.com/)&quot;,
        u&quot; â€¢ Luis Queral (http://luisquer.al)\n&quot;,
        u&quot;view more at: http://soundcloud.com/jumpcityrecords&quot;,
        ])
    description = u&quot;\n&quot;.join(description)
    descriptionfilename = os.path.join(albumdir, &quot;description.txt&quot;)
    with codecs.open(descriptionfilename, &quot;w&quot;, &quot;utf8&quot;) as of:
        of.write(description)

    # Now compose the actual tracks.
    for nr, track in enumerate(tracks):
        trackname, duration = track
        tags = {
            &quot;ALBUM&quot;: albumname,
            &quot;ARTIST&quot;: u&quot;[ jump city records ]&quot;,
            &quot;DATE&quot;: datetime.date.today().isoformat(),
            &quot;TITLE&quot;: trackname,
            &quot;DESCRIPTION&quot;: descriptionfilename,
            &quot;GENRE&quot;: u&quot;Musique ConcrÃ¨te&quot;,
            &quot;COMPOSER&quot;: u&quot;jumpcity.py&quot;,
            &quot;TRACKNUMBER&quot;: nr + 1,
            &quot;TRACKTOTAL&quot;: len(tracks),    
            }
        # Catch exception and re-generate track in case of error.
        while True:
            try:
                trackfilename = composetrack.generate(duration, albumname, trackname, picturefilename, tags)
            except ValueError, e:
                print &quot;ERROR:&quot;, e
                continue
            break
        # Convert problematic characters in filenames, eg. ?, /, \, :, to a space.
        safetrackname = trackname.replace(&quot;?&quot;, &quot; &quot;).replace(&quot;/&quot;, &quot; &quot;).replace(&quot;\\&quot;, &quot; &quot;).replace(&quot;:&quot;, &quot; &quot;)
        destname = u&quot;%02d %s - %s.%s&quot; % (nr + 1, albumname, safetrackname, constants.OUTPUTFORMAT)
        print &quot;\x1b[92m&quot; + &quot;\x1b[1m&quot; &quot;DESTNAME:&quot; + &quot;\x1b[37m&quot;, destname + &quot;\x1b[22m&quot;
        print &quot;&quot;
        print &quot; â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢ â€¢&quot;
        os.rename(trackfilename, os.path.join(albumdir, destname))

    # Clean up
    os.unlink(descriptionfilename)
    print &quot;\x1b[0m&quot;
    return albumdir, albumname


if __name__ == &quot;__main__&quot;:
    if scaup_available:
        client, _ = scaup.login()
    for i in xrange(1):
        albumdir, albumname = generatealbum()
        if scaup_available:
            scaup.upload(client, albumdir, title=albumname, verbose=True)

```

```
# -*- coding: utf8 -*-

&quot;&quot;&quot;
composetrack.py

Create a track from random assets. Software by Michiel Overtoom, motoom@xs4all.nl

- Choose a random directory from the _assets subdirectory.
- Choose three random files in this subdirectory.
- Mix them.

Return the name of the generated track.

TODO: determine (and correct) bitrate. SoX won&#39;t mix soundfiles with different bitrates.
&quot;&quot;&quot;

import os
import random
import glob
import utils
import datetime
import constants


def generate(targetduration=None, albumname=None, trackname=None, picturefilename=None, tags=None, play=False):
    &quot;&quot;&quot; Generate one album track. &quot;&quot;&quot;
    if targetduration is None:
        targetduration = int(random.uniform(constants.TRACKMINDUR, constants.TRACKMAXDUR))

    asset = random.choice([name for name in glob.glob(&quot;../_assets/*&quot;) if os.path.isdir(name)])
    print &quot;\x1b[36m&quot; + &quot;\x1b[1m&quot; + &quot;\n Creating a track from &#39;%s&#39; asset, target duration %s \n&quot; % (asset, utils.seconds2hhmmss(targetduration)) + &quot;\x1b[22m&quot; + &quot;\x1b[37m&quot;
    fns = [fn for fn in glob.glob(os.path.join(asset, &quot;*&quot;)) if not fn.endswith(&quot;.m4a&quot;)]

    mixercmd = &quot;sox -m &quot;
    for nr, fn in enumerate(random.sample(fns, 3)):
        # See how long the sample is.
        success, fndur, errors = utils.soundfileduration(fn)
        if not success:
            raise ValueError(&quot;generate() can&#39;t determine the duration of &#39;%s&#39;: %s&quot; % (fn, errors))
        print &quot;\x1b[1m&quot; + &quot;    Source for layer%d: %s (duration %s)&quot; % (nr, fn, utils.seconds2hhmmss(fndur)) + &quot;\x1b[22m&quot;
        # If sample duration is longer than &#39;targetduration&#39; seconds, select a random fragment from it, and fade it out.
        fade = trim = &quot;&quot;
        if fndur &gt; targetduration:
            trimstart = random.uniform(0, max(0, (fndur - targetduration - 4)))
            trimlength = targetduration
            trim = &quot;trim %d %d&quot; % (trimstart, trimlength)
            print &quot;    ...excerpt from %s to %s (duration %s)&quot; % (utils.seconds2hhmmss(trimstart), utils.seconds2hhmmss(trimstart + trimlength), utils.seconds2hhmmss(trimlength))
            fade = &quot;fade 0 %d 4&quot; % targetduration
            print &quot;    ...fade: %s&quot; % fade
        # If it is shorter than the target duration, repeat it.
        repeat = &quot;&quot;
        if fndur &lt; targetduration:
            repeats = (targetduration - fndur) / fndur
            repeat = &quot;repeat %d&quot; % repeats
            print &quot;    ...repeating, extra %d times (for a total duration of %s)&quot; % (repeats, (repeats + 1) * fndur)
        panning = (
            &quot;remix 1 2&quot;, # No panning for sample #1
            &quot;remix 1 2v0.25&quot;, # Right panning for sample #2
            &quot;remix 1v0.25 2&quot;, # Left panning for sample #3
            )
        layerfn = &quot;layer%d.wav&quot; % nr
        cmd = &#39;sox &quot;%s&quot; &quot;%s&quot; channels 2 rate 44100 %s %s %s %s&#39; % (fn, layerfn, panning[nr], repeat, trim, fade)
        _, errors = utils.soxexecute(cmd)
        if errors:
            raise ValueError(&quot;generate() can&#39;t create layer &#39;%s&#39;: %s&quot; % (layerfn, errors))   
        result, layerdur, errors = utils.soundfileduration(layerfn)
        if errors:
            raise ValueError(&quot;generate() can&#39;t determine duration of &#39;%s&#39;: %s&quot; % (layerfn, errors))   
        print &quot;    ...resulting duration: %s \n&quot; % utils.seconds2hhmmss(layerdur)
        mixercmd += &#39;&quot;%s&quot; &#39; % layerfn

    trackfilename = &quot;track-%s.wav&quot; % datetime.datetime.now().strftime(&quot;%Y-%m-%d.%H-%M-%S&quot;)
    mixercmd += trackfilename
    print &quot;Mixing to %s...&quot; % trackfilename, 
    _, errors = utils.soxexecute(mixercmd)
    if errors:
        raise ValueError(&quot;generate() can&#39;t mix: %s&quot; % (trackfilename, errors))   
    print &quot;&quot;
    print &quot;\x1b[92m&quot; + &quot;\x1b[1m&quot; + &quot;done&quot; + &quot;\x1b[22m&quot; + &quot;\x1b[37m&quot;

    os.system(&quot;rm layer*.wav&quot;) # Remove tempfiles.

    if play:
        os.system(&quot;play -q %s&quot; % trackfilename)

    if constants.OUTPUTFORMAT == &quot;mp3&quot;:
        print &quot;&quot;
        print &quot;Making mp3...&quot;
        id3tags = u&#39; --ta &quot;Jump City Records&quot; --ty %04d&#39; % datetime.date.today().year
        if albumname:
            id3tags += u&#39; --tl &quot;%s&quot;&#39; % albumname
        if trackname:
            id3tags += u&#39; --tt &quot;%s&quot;&#39; % trackname
        cmd = u&quot;lame %s %s&quot; % (id3tags, trackfilename)
        res = os.system(cmd.encode(&quot;utf8&quot;))
        if res != 0:
            print &quot;LAME error %d&quot; % res
            return None
        os.unlink(trackfilename)
        trackfilename = trackfilename.replace(u&quot;.wav&quot;, u&quot;.mp3&quot;)
    elif constants.OUTPUTFORMAT == &quot;flac&quot;:
        print &quot;&quot;
        print &quot;Making flac...&quot;
        pictureclause = u&quot;&quot;
        if picturefilename:
            pictureclause = u&#39;--picture=&quot;%s&quot; &#39; % picturefilename
        tagclause = u&quot;&quot;
        if tags:
            for field, value in tags.iteritems():
                if field == &quot;DESCRIPTION&quot;:
                    tagclause += u&#39;--tag-from-file=%s=&quot;%s&quot; &#39; % (field, value)
                else:
                    tagclause += u&#39;--tag=%s=&quot;%s&quot; &#39; % (field, value)                    
        cmd = u&#39;flac -s -f -8 --delete-input-file %s %s &quot;%s&quot;&#39; % (pictureclause, tagclause, trackfilename)
        res = os.system(cmd.encode(&quot;utf8&quot;))
        if res != 0:
            print &quot;flac error %d&quot; % res
            return None
        trackfilename = trackfilename.replace(&quot;.wav&quot;, &quot;.flac&quot;)
    else:

```

<details><summary>Tool use: **command** â€¢ Run command: curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/luismqueral/jumpcityrecords/master/src/albumtracks.py" | head -80</summary>

```bash
curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/luismqueral/jumpcityrecords/master/src/albumtracks.py" | head -80
```

```
# -*- coding: utf8 -*-

&quot;&quot;&quot;
albumtracks.py

Generate meta-data (name, tracknames, durations etc...) for an album. Software by Michiel Overtoom, motoom@xs4all.nl
&quot;&quot;&quot;

import marshal
import codecs
import random
import sys
sys.path.append(&quot;..&quot;)
import utils
import constants
import datetime


class AlbumTracks(object):
    def __init__(self):
        # The file &#39;titles.dat&#39; has been prepared by &#39;parse.py&#39;.
        self.titles = marshal.load(open(&quot;titles.dat&quot;, &quot;rb&quot;))
        # Divide the titels into english and non-english.
        english_titles = set()
        non_english_titles = set()
        for lang, titleset in self.titles.iteritems():
            if lang == &quot;en&quot;:
                english_titles = english_titles.union(self.titles[lang])
            else:
                non_english_titles = non_english_titles.union(self.titles[lang])
        self.english_titles = list(english_titles)
        self.non_english_titles = list(non_english_titles)


    def randomtitle(self, allowparentheses=True):
        while True:
            if utils.rnd(100) &lt; 80:
                name = random.choice(self.english_titles)
            else:
                name = random.choice(self.non_english_titles)
            if not allowparentheses and (&quot;(&quot; in name or &quot;)&quot; in name):
                continue
            return name
            
                
    def generatetrack(self):
        duration = int(random.uniform(constants.TRACKMINDUR, constants.TRACKMAXDUR + 1))
        name = self.randomtitle()
        return name, duration


    def generatealbum(self):
        title = self.randomtitle(False)
        datestamp = datetime.datetime.now().strftime(&quot;%Y-%m-%d / %H:%M:%S&quot;)
        trackcount = int(random.uniform(constants.MINTRACKSPERALBUM, constants.MAXTRACKSPERALBUM + 1))
        seen = set()
        tracks = []
        while len(tracks) &lt; trackcount:
            candidate = self.generatetrack()
            name, _ = candidate
            if name not in seen: # Avoid duplicate track names.
                tracks.append(candidate)
                seen.add(name)
        return title, datestamp, tracks


    def htmlexample(self):
        ofn = &quot;albumtracks.html&quot;
        with codecs.open(ofn, &quot;w&quot;, &quot;utf8&quot;) as of:
            of.write(u&quot;&quot;&quot;&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;
                &lt;html&gt;
                &lt;head&gt;
                    &lt;meta http-equiv=&quot;content-type&quot; content=&quot;text/html; charset=utf-8&quot; /&gt;
                    &lt;style&gt;
                        body {

                            font-family: Monaco, monospace;

                        td {
```

```diff
  The illustration above was done by [Matt Carignan](http://mattcarignan.com/).
  
- ## How It Works
- 
- When the script runs, it randomly assigns:
- 
- - **Album title** â€” pulled from random Wikipedia article titles
- - **Number of tracks** â€” between 3-8
- - **Track titles** â€” also from Wikipedia (*&quot;Yuuka Maeda&quot;*, *&quot;Tartu Town Hall&quot;*)
- - **Track durations** â€” 15 seconds to 6 minutes each
- 
- The audio is entirely sample-based. Samples come from field recordings, avant-garde albums, and other sourcesâ€”mostly downloaded from archive.org. The script selects a folder, grabs three random audio samples, layers them in SoX, applies a chain of effects, and exports the master as FLAC.
-

- â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”

- â”‚  3 Random Samples   â”‚  â†’ Layered in SoX

- â”‚   Effects Chain     â”‚  â†’ Distortion, reverb, etc.
- â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
-        â”‚

- â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
- â”‚   Album Art         â”‚  â†’ Generated via Cairo
- â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

-        ğŸµ .flac
- &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ ## Architecture
+ 
+ The system is modular, with each Python file handling a specific responsibility:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ src/
+ â”œâ”€â”€ jumpcity.py      # Main orchestrator
+ â”œâ”€â”€ albumtracks.py   # Metadata generation (titles, durations)
+ â”œâ”€â”€ composetrack.py  # Audio synthesis and mixing
+ â”œâ”€â”€ albumart.py      # Cairo-based cover generation
+ â”œâ”€â”€ constants.py     # Configuration (min/max durations, track counts)
+ â””â”€â”€ utils.py         # SoX helpers, duration detection
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### The Orchestrator: &#96;jumpcity.py&#96;
+ 
+ The main driver coordinates the full pipeline:
+ 
+ 1. Generate album metadata (name, tracks, durations)
+ 2. Render album art via Cairo
+ 3. Compose each track from random samples
+ 4. Tag the output files with FLAC metadata
+ 5. Optionally upload to SoundCloud via &#96;scaup&#96;
+ 
+ ### Title Generation: &#96;albumtracks.py&#96;
+ 
+ Titles come from a pre-parsed Wikipedia dump (&#96;titles.dat&#96;). The system:
+ 
+ - Maintains separate pools of English vs. non-English titles
+ - Weights 80% English, 20% other languages
+ - Filters out parenthetical disambiguations for album titles
+ - Ensures no duplicate track names within an album
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;python
+ if utils.rnd(100) &lt; 80:
+     name = random.choice(self.english_titles)
+ else:
+     name = random.choice(self.non_english_titles)
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### Audio Synthesis: &#96;composetrack.py&#96;
+ 
+ This is where the actual music happens. For each track:
+ 
+ 1. **Select an asset folder** â€” Random choice from &#96;_assets/&#96;
+ 2. **Pick 3 samples** â€” Random files from that folder
+ 3. **Process each layer:**
+    - Normalize to stereo 44.1kHz
+    - If longer than target: trim a random excerpt + fade out
+    - If shorter than target: loop/repeat
+    - Apply stereo panning (center, left, right)
+ 4. **Mix layers** â€” &#96;sox -m layer0.wav layer1.wav layer2.wav track.wav&#96;
+ 5. **Encode** â€” Convert to FLAC with embedded artwork and tags
+ 
+ The panning creates stereo width:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;python
+ panning = (
+     &quot;remix 1 2&quot;,        # Layer 0: center
+     &quot;remix 1 2v0.25&quot;,   # Layer 1: right
+     &quot;remix 1v0.25 2&quot;,   # Layer 2: left
+ )
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### Album Art: &#96;albumart.py&#96;
+ 
+ Cover art is generated programmatically using Cairo (Python bindings). Each cover includes:
+ 
+ - Album title
+ - Track listing with durations
+ - Timestamp
+ - Credits
+ 
+ The typography uses Transport Medium and Apercu fonts when available.
+ 
+ ## Configuration
+ 
+ All the magic numbers live in &#96;constants.py&#96;:
+ 
+ | Parameter | Default |
+ |-----------|---------|
+ | Min track duration | 15 seconds |
+ | Max track duration | 6 minutes |
+ | Min tracks per album | 3 |
+ | Max tracks per album | 8 |
+ | Output format | FLAC |
  
  ## Example Output
```

<details><summary>Tool use: **code_edit** â€¢ Edit file: /Users/luisqueral/Projects/studio-queral-2026/src/components/AsciinemaPlayer.jsx</summary>

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,78 @@
- 
+ import { useEffect, useRef } from &#39;react&#39;;
+ 
+ /**
+  * Asciinema Player Component
+  * Embeds an asciinema terminal recording
+  */
+ export function AsciinemaPlayer({ src, rows = 24, cols = 80, autoPlay = false, loop = false, speed = 1 }) {
+   const containerRef = useRef(null);
+   const playerRef = useRef(null);
+ 
+   useEffect(() =&gt; {
+     // Dynamically load the asciinema-player library
+     const loadPlayer = async () =&gt; {
+       if (typeof window === &#39;undefined&#39;) return;
+       
+       // Load CSS if not already loaded
+       if (!document.querySelector(&#39;link[href*=&quot;asciinema-player&quot;]&#39;)) {
+         const link = document.createElement(&#39;link&#39;);
+         link.rel = &#39;stylesheet&#39;;
+         link.href = &#39;https://unpkg.com/asciinema-player@3.6.1/dist/bundle/asciinema-player.css&#39;;
+         document.head.appendChild(link);
+       }
+ 
+       // Load JS if not already loaded
+       if (!window.AsciinemaPlayer) {
+         await new Promise((resolve, reject) =&gt; {
+           const script = document.createElement(&#39;script&#39;);
+           script.src = &#39;https://unpkg.com/asciinema-player@3.6.1/dist/bundle/asciinema-player.min.js&#39;;
+           script.onload = resolve;
+           script.onerror = reject;
+           document.head.appendChild(script);
+         });
+       }
+ 
+       // Create player
+       if (containerRef.current &amp;&amp; window.AsciinemaPlayer &amp;&amp; !playerRef.current) {
+         playerRef.current = window.AsciinemaPlayer.create(
+           src,
+           containerRef.current,
+           {
+             rows,
+             cols,
+             autoPlay,
+             loop,
+             speed,
+             theme: &#39;monokai&#39;,
+             fit: &#39;width&#39;,
+             terminalFontFamily: &quot;&#39;IBM Plex Mono&#39;, Monaco, Menlo, monospace&quot;,
+           }
+         );
+       }
+     };
+ 
+     loadPlayer();
+ 
+     return () =&gt; {
+       if (playerRef.current &amp;&amp; playerRef.current.dispose) {
+         playerRef.current.dispose();
+         playerRef.current = null;
+       }
+     };
+   }, [src, rows, cols, autoPlay, loop, speed]);
+ 
+   return (
+     &lt;div 
+       ref={containerRef} 
+       style={{ 
+         width: &#39;100%&#39;, 
+         borderRadius: &#39;8px&#39;, 
+         overflow: &#39;hidden&#39;,
+         margin: &#39;1.5em 0&#39;
+       }} 
+     /&gt;
+   );
+ }
+ 
+ export default AsciinemaPlayer;
+ 
```

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Done. I've made the following performance improvements:

1. **Intersection Observer** â€” Only loads when the player is about to be visible (100px margin)
2. **client:visible** â€” Astro directive that only hydrates when element enters viewport
3. **requestIdleCallback** â€” Loads during browser idle time when available
4. **idleTimeLimit={1}** â€” Skips long pauses in the recording (faster playback)
5. **autoPlay={true}** â€” Starts playing automatically once loaded
6. **Placeholder** â€” Shows a dark background with "Loading terminal..." while loading</details></think>

---

Updated with performance optimizations:

**Lazy loading:**
- `client:visible` â€” Only hydrates the component when it enters the viewport
- Intersection Observer with 100px margin â€” Starts loading just before visible
- `requestIdleCallback` â€” Loads during browser idle time

**Playback:**
- `autoPlay={true}` â€” Starts automatically when loaded
- `idleTimeLimit={1}` â€” Skips pauses longer than 1 second (faster demo)
- `speed={2}` â€” Already set to 2x speed

**UX:**
- Shows dark placeholder with "Loading terminal..." while loading
- Smooth transition when player appears

The recording won't load until you scroll near it, then it starts playing automatically.

```diff
+ 
```
```diff
+ The idea behind lateral thinking is simple: when you&#39;re stuck, a direct assault on the problem rarely works. Instead, you approach it sidewaysâ€”through constraints, provocations, or deliberate disruptions that break your habitual patterns.
+ 
+ Eno and Schmidt&#39;s original cards offered cryptic prompts like *&quot;Honor thy error as a hidden intention&quot;* and *&quot;What would your closest friend do?&quot;* They were designed for musicians, but the principle applies anywhere creative work happens.
+ 
+ My collection expands on this concept with prompts drawn from psychology, history, science, philosophy, and artâ€”each offering a different lens through which to view a problem.
```
