```diff
+ I&#39;ve been collecting creative thinking promptsâ€”strategies that help approach design challenges from unexpected angles. They&#39;re inspired by [Oblique Strategies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oblique_Strategies), the deck of cards created by Brian Eno and Peter Schmidt in 1975.
+ 
+ The idea behind lateral thinking is simple: when you&#39;re stuck, a direct assault on the problem rarely works. Instead, you approach it sidewaysâ€”through constraints, provocations, or deliberate disruptions that break your habitual patterns.
+ 
+ Eno and Schmidt&#39;s original cards offered cryptic prompts like *&quot;Honor thy error as a hidden intention&quot;* and *&quot;What would your closest friend do?&quot;* They were designed for musicians, but the principle applies anywhere creative work happens.

+ My collection expands on this concept with prompts drawn from psychology, history, science, philosophy, and artâ€”each offering a different lens through which to view a problem.
+ 
+ ## How to Use Them
+ 
+ Pick a strategy that feels relevant (or deliberately irrelevant) to your current challenge:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ I&#39;m working on [describe your project briefly]. 
+ 
+ Please apply the &quot;Honor the Shadows&quot; strategy to help me 
+ think about this differently.
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+

+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ Select 5 random strategies and apply each one to 
+ [describe your project]. Give me distinct perspectives

+ 
+ ## Some Favorites
+ 
+ ### Honor the Shadows
+ *Theme: Psychology*
+ 
+ &gt; What exists in the shadows of this project, unacknowledged? Identify the overlooked aspects, the negative spaces, or the deliberately ignored elements. Sometimes the most profound insights are found not in the light, but in what we&#39;ve chosen to leave in the dark.
+ 
+ ### Follow the Resistance
+ *Theme: Philosophy*
+ 
+ &gt; Where do you feel resistance, friction, or difficulty? Instead of overcoming these, follow them deliberately. What happens when you move *toward* what resists you?
+ 
+ ### Break the Container
+ *Theme: Philosophy*
+ 
+ &gt; What invisible containersâ€”assumptions, frameworks, boundariesâ€”currently hold this work? Identify them precisely. Then, deliberately shatter at least one. What spills out?
+ 
+ ### Excavate the Palimpsest
+ *Theme: History*
+ 
+ &gt; Approach this situation as a palimpsestâ€”a manuscript with layers of text written, erased, and overwritten across time. What earlier inscriptions remain partially visible beneath current narratives?
+ 
+ ### Apply Quantum Tunneling
+ *Theme: Science*
+ 
+ &gt; Consider this through quantum tunneling: particles passing through impenetrable barriers. What supposedly insurmountable obstacles might be traversed by probability, not force?
+ 
+ ### Invoke Dadaist Disruption
+ *Theme: Art*
+ 
+ &gt; Apply Dadaist principles. What happens when you deliberately introduce chaos, absurdity, or anti-logic into the process?
+ 
+ ## The Full Collection
+ 
+ The complete set includes strategies drawn from:
+ 
+ - **Psychology** â€” Shadow work, resistance, cognitive reframing
+ - **History** â€” Phoenician trading, Ottoman governance, Hanseatic cooperation
+ - **Science** â€” Quantum mechanics, systems thinking, emergence
+ - **Philosophy** â€” Stoicism, Zen, phenomenology
+ - **Art** â€” Dadaism, minimalism, found objects
+ 
+ The goal isn&#39;t to find &quot;the answer&quot;â€”it&#39;s to generate new angles, to see what you couldn&#39;t see before. Like Eno&#39;s original cards, they work best when you commit to following wherever the prompt leads, even when it feels irrelevant or uncomfortable.
+ 
+ **Source:** [studio-queral-context/misc/strategies.md](https://github.com/luismqueral/studio-queral-context/blob/main/misc/strategies.md)
```

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,162 @@
- 
+ ---
+ title: &quot;How To Attend Meetings&quot;
+ description: &quot;A framework for deciding which meetings deserve your timeâ€”and how to make the most of them.&quot;
+ date: 2024-03-15
+ tags: [&quot;productivity&quot;, &quot;work&quot;, &quot;meetings&quot;, &quot;time-management&quot;]
+ draft: false
+ ---
+ 
+ *Originally presented by Brian Peterson, Product @ The New York Times*
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ If your calendar looks anything like this, you might have a problem:
+ 
+ ![Chaotic calendar view](/images/blog/how-to-attend-meetings/page-001.png)
+ 
+ The good news? **Attending a meeting is a choice.**
+ 
+ ## How Not to Choose
+ 
+ When deciding whether to attend a meeting, don&#39;t base your decision on:
+ 
+ - **Urgency** â€” Just because something feels urgent doesn&#39;t mean it requires your presence
+ - **Importance** â€” Important topics can often be handled asynchronously
+ - **Seniority** â€” The person&#39;s title shouldn&#39;t automatically command your time
+ - **Calendar availability** â€” An open slot doesn&#39;t mean you should fill it
+ 
+ ## How to Choose
+ 
+ Instead, use this simple decision framework:
+ 
+ ![Meeting decision flowchart](/images/blog/how-to-attend-meetings/page-004.png)
+ 
+ 1. **Can I contribute or gain a unique perspective at this meeting?**
+    - If No â†’ Decline
+    - If Yes â†’ Continue to step 2
+ 
+ 2. **Does this perspective have value?**
+    - If No â†’ Decline
+    - If Yes â†’ Attend
+ 
+ ## Meeting Agendas Are the Key
+ 
+ Agendas clarify the outcome of the meeting. If there is no clear outcome, contributions are unlikely to have value.
+ 
+ **Your attendance at a meeting deserves an agenda.**
+ 
+ ### No agenda? Ask for one!
+ 
+ &gt; &quot;Could you please add an agenda to this meeting invite? I want to make sure I know how to prepare for this meeting so I can make the best use of your time.&quot;
+ 
+ ### Responding Before Declining
+ 
+ Before declining, consider asking:
+ 
+ - &quot;How should I prepare for this meeting?&quot;
+ - &quot;What are you looking to hear from me in this meeting?&quot;
+ 
+ ## Red Flags
+ 
+ Watch out for these warning signs:
+ 
+ - **Meetings over 30 minutes** â€” Most decisions can be made faster
+ - **Recurring meetings of any duration or frequency** â€” Question their necessity regularly
+ - **Meetings with no agenda that are not 1-on-1s** â€” These rarely produce value
+ - **Optional meetings** â€” If you&#39;re optional, you probably don&#39;t need to be there
+ - **Meetings with agendas that are not about making a decision, brainstorming, or rallying the troops** â€” What&#39;s the point?
+ - **Meetings with descriptions focused on discussion without clear outcomes** â€” Discussion alone isn&#39;t a goal
+ 
+ ## Meeting Flavors
+ 
+ Meetings come in different flavors across three dimensions:
+ 
+ | Purpose | Size | Communication Style |
+ |---------|------|-------------------|
+ | Giving Feedback | 1-on-1s | Synchronous |
+ | Sharing | Leads | Asynchronous |
+ | Discussing | Small | Detailed |
+ | Updating | Medium | High-Level |
+ | Deciding | Large | Functional |
+ | Brainstorming | | Cross-Functional |
+ | Rallying the Troops | | |
+ 
+ ### Good Meeting Flavor Combinations
+ 
+ Like chocolate and peanut butter, some combinations just work:
+ 
+ ![Good meeting combinations](/images/blog/how-to-attend-meetings/page-010.png)
+ 
+ - **Large + Rallying the Troops** â€” All-hands, team celebrations
+ - **Small + Deciding + Leads + High-Level** â€” Executive decisions
+ - **Medium + Updating + Asynchronous** â€” Status updates (async!)
+ - **Small + Discussing + Functional + Detailed** â€” Working sessions
+ - **1-on-1 + Giving Feedback** â€” Performance conversations
+ - **Medium + Brainstorming + Cross-Functional** â€” Creative sessions
+ 
+ ### Bad Meeting Flavor Combinations
+ 
+ Like marinara on vanilla cake, some combinations don&#39;t work:
+ 
+ ![Bad meeting combinations](/images/blog/how-to-attend-meetings/page-011.png)
+ 
+ - **Small + Brainstorming** â€” Not enough perspectives
+ - **Large + Deciding** â€” Too many cooks
+ - **Large + Updating** â€” Could be an email
+ - **Anything but 1-on-1 + Giving Feedback** â€” Feedback should be private
+ - **Asynchronous + Rallying the Troops** â€” Energy doesn&#39;t translate
+ - **Large + Discussing** â€” Chaos
+ 
+ ## Real Meeting Invite Examples
+ 
+ ### Example 1: The Red Flag Meeting
+ 
+ | Field | Value |
+ |-------|-------|
+ | Title | Discuss Important Project |
+ | Duration | 45 minutes |
+ | Guests | 14 guests |
+ | Recurrence | None |
+ | Description | None |
+ 
+ **Analysis:** 45 minutes Ã· 14 guests = **3.2 minutes of speaking per guest**. Will you be speaking more or less than average? Will hearing other people speak be valuable to you? And where&#39;s the agenda?
+ 
+ ### Example 2: The Recurring Update
+ 
+ | Field | Value |
+ |-------|-------|
+ | Title | Important Project that sometimes involves you |
+ | Duration | 30 minutes |
+ | Guests | 21 guests |
+ | Recurrence | Weekly |
+ | Description | Weekly check in to review Important Project execution. See plan for details |
+ 
+ **Analysis:** 30 minutes Ã· 21 guests = **1.43 minutes of speaking per guest**. Is this a standup? Will you have something important to share or learn in *each* meeting? Consider checking the plan each week and deciding to attend based on the contents and whether you will have something important to share and learn.
+ 
+ ### Example 3: The Good Meeting
+ 
+ | Field | Value |
+ |-------|-------|
+ | Title | Decisions on Important Projects |
+ | Duration | 60 minutes |
+ | Guests | 8 guests |
+ | Recurrence | None |
+ | Description | Our team would like to decide whether to move forward with 2 Important Projects. 1:00pm-1:30pm: Project A (You are only needed for this part). 1:30pm-2:00pm: Project B (You are not needed for this part)... |
+ 
+ **Analysis:** Making decisions is a great reason to meet! 60 minutes Ã· 8 guests = **7.5 minutes of speaking per guest** â€” now we&#39;re talking! And with a detailed agenda, you can also choose to attend only the relevant half of this meeting.
+ 
+ ## What Else Can I Do to Protect My Time?
+ 
+ ![Calendar with lunch blocked](/images/blog/how-to-attend-meetings/page-019.png)
+ 
+ **Schedule recurring time for things you know you need to do:**
+ 
+ - **Lunch** â€” cause you gotta eat
+ - **Prep time** before presentations or meetings you&#39;re hosting
+ - **Focus time** for deep work
+ - **Buffer time** between meetings
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ *Remember: Your time is valuable. Every meeting you attend is time you&#39;re not spending on deep work, creative thinking, or simply recovering your energy. Choose wisely.*
+ 
```
